ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Students will gain a lot of insight about democracy promotion, both by the U.S. and other actors. A lot of interesting content, including about election observers/monitoring, unintended consequences of democracy promotion, what is democracy promotion, history of democracy promotion, etc.

Content: explored the historical legacies of democracy promotion, democracy promotion's various mechanisms, and possible implementations, and the United States' (and the West's) complex involvement with democracy promotion, etc.
This is a really interesting and practical course that talks at great length about American foreign policy relating to democracy promotion.
Learned more about democracy promotion, but not that much about its critics. This is probably the biggest weakness of the class.
I learned how to read and analyze political science papers and improved my discussion skills. I came away with a deep understanding of democracy promotion and its flaws/benefits.
New concepts about foreign policy, international relations, and democracy
I really enjoyed this class and learned a lot

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Extremely interesting readings and very dynamic in-class conversations. Professor Bush is always open to giving feedback to students and meeting with them to discuss the class and assignments.

Strengths: Professor Bush! She knows everything about the topic and cares about it.  The material was interesting; everyone loved the week on the Color Revolutions and for good reason. Other weeks were a bit more hit or miss, but Professor Bush clearly thought a lot about her pieces! The guest speakers were also super cool; I wish we had more. Weaknesses: there wasn't a lot of discussion on the "its critiques" part of the name - the course assumed that democracy is a priori a good thing regardless, which is maybe not always so clear. The course was a hybrid political history and international relations course, and some weeks felt disconnected. While each reading was interesting, the course should be tinkered with in the future (especially the disjointedness of the response papers / final paper).
The readings and writing assignments were very interesting, though sometimes class discussions seemed to lack the same vigor and enthusiasm.
The class has interesting topics, but the readings and professor are relatively bland. To be honest, there are better seminars out there, but the professor is very nice and helpful

Strengths: Interesting and engaging professor, relevant material, great readings
Weaknesses: Discussions can be a bit disjointed and not everybody seemed super engaged
Great readings, class discussion was a little stale even the members of the class were excited to discuss because of the breadth of the material
I learned a lot about NGOs and democracy promotion programs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Would highly recommend to any student interested in democracy promotion, international affairs, U.S. foreign policy, etc.

I would say yes; this is very much an "international relations" seminar. At times discussions felt uncomfortably US-centric, and most of the readings were Western-centric. This makes sense given the content, but the most engaging weeks were from the perspective of non-western states (for instance, the Color Revolutions and Otpor!). The material is not for everyone, but it's interesting, and even if you're against democracy promotion, you could get a lot of useful history from the course. Professor Bush is lovely and cares a lot for her students; she had a difficult semester health-wise and made the best of it, which I admire her for!

This is an interesting course to take if you know a fair amount about American foreign policy and want to learn more specifically about democracy promotion. Professor Bush is wonderful and the material is engaging.
I would recommend to a freshman or sophomore, but not to upperclassmen because there are much better seminars out there.
Yes! The class is very interesting and relevant, and Professor Bush is super knowledgeable. Do be prepared to do a lot of writing, though.
Interesting material, although you do not get a lot of feedback
Yes! It was amazing
